section.name: Introduction
section.t: Determining a suitable maximum packet size (known as the Path MTU, PMTU) for end-to-end communication remains a persistent challenge in the current Internet.

While many network infrastructure devices in large-scale networks support jumbo Ethernet frames (e.g., 9K), and larger MTUs offer demonstrable benefits in reduced packet processing overhead per byte of data, their practical deployment remains largely confined to isolated environments, such as data centers.
Currently, endpoints and applications employ three primary MTU management approaches:

li.t: Interface-based MTU with Path MTU Discovery (PMTUD): This approach utilizes the MTU configured on the network interface, relying on PMTUD to dynamically reduce packet sizes when necessary. In Ethernet networks, this typically defaults to 1500 bytes. However, network administrators often advertise reduced MTU in RAs to mitigate potential MTU issues, particularly in networks employing tunnels.

Interface-based MTU with Packetization Layer Path MTU Discovery (PLPMTUD): The MTU configured for the network interface constrains the maximum packet size that can be sent. It start from a minimum PMTU, and then sends packet probes on the path to discover whether a specific path can supports a larger packet size.

Fixed Lower MTU: This method employs a fixed, empirically derived MTU. For example, a 2017 Google experiment [La17] using Chrome's experimentation framework tested gQUIC reachability across 25,000 endpoints. The study examined UDP payload sizes from 1200 to 1500 bytes, in 5-byte increments. Results indicated that 5% of tested paths could not support packet sizes exceeding 1370 bytes, and 16% could not support sizes exceeding 1450 bytes. Consequently, gQUIC adopted a fixed packet size of 1350 bytes. The IETF QUIC protocol subsequently reduced the default packet size to 1280 bytes, which is a commonly selected datagram packet size for designs unable to adapt the message size .

section.t: At the same time the Path MTU Discovery remains fragile and unreliable, as discussed in Section 1.1 of .

section.name: Terminology
section.t: Default MTU: a new term, introduced by this document, referring to the MTU that the sender uses for data until an explicit signal is received, indicating that a larger MTU can be used.
MAX_PLPMTU: the largest size of the packet the sender will attempt to use (see ).
Legacy node: a node which does not implement protocol changes or algorithms proposed by this document.
Updated node: a node which supports Large MTUs and implements protocol changes and/or algorithms proposed by this document.
Large MTU: an MTU above 1500 bytes.
Large MTU link: a link which supports a Large MTU
Legacy link: a link that does not support Large MTU (i.e., a link with an MTU equal to or lower than 1500 bytes).
Link MTU: The configured link MTU size in bytes of the largest IP packet, including the IP header and payload, that can be transmitted over a link. See .
Probe Packet: a test packet that can be larger than the Default MTU and cannot exceed the Link MTU, and used to test a path (see Section 4.1 of ).

section.name: Problem Statement
section.t: Even when a link supports a Large MTU, two challenges emerge:

li.t: All nodes on a link need to utilize the same MTU value (e.g., advertised via the MTU RA option or derived from explicit or implicit interface configuration). An administrator cannot configure nodes with a larger MTU until all nodes on the link are updated to support this.

When a node is configured with a Large MTU on its interface (either through an MTU RA option or other means), it can employ that MTU as a default starting value for all communications, both on-link and off-link. While all links within an administrative domain could support a Large MTU, it is improbable that all Internet paths do. The node will inevitably encounter a range of PMTU values when communicating with Internet destinations.

Incremental deployment: the legacy and update nodes MUST be able to coexist on the same large MTU link or a legacy link. The solution MUST allow an operator to migrate individual links and individual nodes to support the Large MTU.
Legacy and updated nodes MUST be able to communicate both onlink and over any combination of large MTU and legacy links.
Two updated nodes MUST select the largest possible MTU to use to communicate over the path.

section.name: Modification to the Neighbor Discovery protocol
section.t: This document introduces a new Neighbor Discovery option, called LMTU (Large MTU). This option may be used in Router Advertisement and Neighbor Adevrtisement messages.

li.t: When present in a Router Advertisement message, it indicates the large MTU value to be used on the link to all updated nodes.

When present in a Neighbor Adevrtisement message, it indicates that the sender supports a large MTU. If an on-link receiver is an updated node, it can use this value as the MTU when communicating with the sender. If the receiver is off-link, then the sender can discover the PMTU up to this size. section.t: Legacy nodes ignore the LMTU option.

For large MTU links, the router SHOULD include both MTU options: new LMTU option to indicate to the updated nodes the large MTU to use onlink, and the MTU option defined in Section 4.6.4 of . The legacy hosts will ignore the new LMTU option and use the latter as the link MTU. The updated hosts use the old MTU option as the Default MTU and include the LMTU option (or set the bit????) in NA.

section.name: Legacy and Updated Hosts on a legacy link
section.t: The router ether does not include any MTU options, or only includes the legacy MTU option. (Bob: Describe this as RFC4861 MTU options??) The updated host processes the legacy MTU option and uses that MTU value, or, if it's not present, a link MTU as the Default MTU to communicate to all onlink hosts and to offlink destinations.

section.name: Legacy and Updated Hosts on a large MTU link
section.t: The router includes both options. The legacy host ignores the LMTU option and use the MTU option as a link MTU. The updated host processes the LMTU option but initially will not to use this for any destination. Instead it will use the MTU option value as the Default MTU for an initial MTU for all new communications. When sending an NA to the legacy host, the updated host includes the LMTU option into the NA. The legacy host ignores the option, and both hosts use the legacy MTU.

section.name: Two Updated Hosts on a legacy MTU link
section.t: Similar to Legacy and Updated Hosts on a legacy link. (Bob: I think this means that can't use Large MTUs unless the Router says (by including the LMTU option) it thinks the link is capable. Correct?)

section.name: Two Updated Hosts on a large MTU link
section.t: The router includes two options. The updated hosts processes the LMTU option but initially is not going to use it for any destinations. Instead it will be using the MTU option as the Default MTU as an initial MTU for all new communications. When sending an NA to an onlink neighbor, the updated host includes the LMTU option into the NA. The neighbor processes the option, updates the Neighbor Cache with the LMTU value, and uses it when communicating with the host advertizing the large MTU.

section.name: Updated Host Communicating to an off-link Destination
section.t: The host will be using the legacy MTU value advertized by the router as the initial MTU value, until some other mechanisms provide an explicit signal that a large MTU can be used. Such mechanisms can include the values between the legacy and the Large MTU in probing. This allows use the large MTU if the path supports it.
